awd_titl_txt: SHF: Small: A Versatile, Adaptive Network Architecture for Combating Traffic Heterogeneity in Data Centers
awd_abstract_narration:
Driven by technology advances, massive data centers consisting of tens or even hundreds of thousands servers have been built as infrastructures by large online service providers, in which the performance of data center networks plays a critical role. Traffic in data center networks (DCNs) generally exhibits tremendous heterogeneous characteristics, at different locations in the network, among various applications, between distinct companyís implementations, and from time to time. On the other hand, today's data center networks still lack sufficient flexibility to handle such huge heterogeneity of traffic in an efficient way. Meanwhile, as virtualization techniques undergo a profound development, cloud applications do not directly run on physical hardware or operating systems. Instead, they are assigned on a simulated operating system layer which is virtualized from a substrate network. Thus, a single infrastructure provider can support numerous virtual machines/networks for different users while keeping each user with a vision that the entire infrastructure is uniquely occupied by the user. To meet the challenges, this research designs a versatile network architecture oriented to the ever-increasing performance demands and heterogeneous traffic characteristics of today's data centers. The architecture provides an adaptive full-stack paradigm which includes interconnect topologies, addressing and routing schemes, and virtualization algorithms. 

More specifically, the research focuses on several closely coupled issues: (1) design a novel, cost-efficient DCN architecture that can dynamically and systematically handle traffic heterogeneity in data centers; (2) design the corresponding routing algorithms for the architecture under unicast and multicast traffic models; (3) develop efficient network virtualization algorithms in the architecture, including virtual network embedding, virtual network function placement and virtualization over geographically distributed DCNs; (4) conduct a comprehensive performance evaluation through extensive simulations and implementation of the schemes in a realistic network prototype. The research combines theoretical analysis, algorithm design, network optimization, simulation and prototyping techniques to provide a comprehensive working solution that enables high performance next generation DCNs. This research is expected have a profound impact on fundamental design principles of future DCNs. The outcome of this research will not only greatly boost the performance of DCN flexibility and energy efficiency while keeping low cost, but also facilitate numerous cloud computing applications currently hosted in data centers. As cloud computing is penetrating into all aspects of the society, this research will have a broader impact on the society and help change the world.

por.por_cntn:
As the foundation of cloud computing, data centers are pivotal in shaping the economic landscape. With the emergence of new applications, such as big data and artificial intelligence, the demand for data centers has grown significantly. Large-scale data centers, serving as the infrastructure for various network services, can house tens of thousands or even hundreds of thousands of servers. The diverse services offered by different companies result in heterogeneity in data center traffic and have different requirements. Consequently, this project focuses on designing data center network topologies tailored for heterogeneous environments, developing corresponding unicast and multicast routing algorithms, and designing and related network virtualization techniques.

Traffic locality significantly influences the performance of distributed processing and plays a decisive role in data center costs. In this project, we crafted several network topologies optimized for localized traffic within data center networks. First, we designed network topologies that adaptively fit traffic locality in Clos-type data center networks and provided its addressing and routing schemes. The proposed approach optimizes the use of network devices, significantly reducing the cost of the network infrastructure. In addition, we introduced a flexible network architecture for data centers called VFTree. This design allows for highly customizable topology and performance, enabling the architecture to adapt seamlessly to the demands of the running traffic. Compared to its counterparts, the VFTree architecture provides enhanced aggregate bandwidth and a broader range of path options at a similar cost. Additionally, we devised data center network topologies to improve cost efficiency, availability, and power efficiency.

Multicast, sending data from a single source to multiple destinations simultaneously, is vital for parallel computing and finds its applications in emerging technology trends like the Google File System. In this project, we designed a cost-efficient interconnection network with multicast capability. We first designed a network named the Multicast Capable Low-cost Network (MCL). We proposed routing algorithms for MCL and then proved its multicast nonblocking properties. In addition, the proposed MCL boasts exceptional cost efficiency, setting a new benchmark for hardware costs compared to previous solutions offering the same performance.

Network Function Virtualization (NFV) is an innovative paradigm that transitions network functions like Proxies, Firewalls, and Load Balancers from specialized hardware to commercial servers. This shift offers enhanced flexibility, scalability, and cost-effectiveness to network services. In this project, we undertook several studies about NFV. First, we developed virtual network function placement and flow routing algorithms under different settings. For hybrid data center networks where each top-on-rank switch is installed with a directional antenna, we formulated a joint VNF placement and antenna scheduling model and designed corresponding algorithms to solve it. For hybrid edge-and-cloud networks, we formulated a service function chain placement problem aimed at concurrently optimizing both resource cost and latency and proposed an algorithm with a provable approximation ratio.

Virtualized network functions face challenges in availability due to inevitable hardware and software failures. This project improves the availability of virtualized network functions by deploying redundant backups. We propose a novel reliability-aware adaptive deployment strategy to efficiently place and back up service function chains over both the edge and the cloud. Initially, the strategy focuses on maximizing edge resource utilization for service function chain deployment. It then leverages both static and on-the-fly dynamic backups to ensure availability, even within the resource constraints of edge networks. Notably, our scheme does not rely on predicted failure rates of virtualized network functions; instead, it seeks an optimal balance between the targeted availability of service function chains and the associated backup expenses.
